Post: "I'm always feeling like a fraud, like I'm not being my true self. I've changed so much since high school, and I feel disconnected from my friends and family. I'm constantly struggling to find my place in the world and feel like I'm just going through the motions of life. I long to be myself again, to feel that sense of freedom and authenticity that I once had. But for now, I'm stuck in this rut, feeling lost and uncertain about my future."

Post:
"I've been struggling with depression for 4 years now, and it feels like it's only getting worse. I feel like I'm all alone in this fight, and that no one truly understands what I'm going through. My parents don't seem to care, they never show me any affection or support. I've been bullied by my classmates, and it's hard to keep up with my grades and maintain any sense of self-esteem. It feels like everything is just piling up on me, and I don't know how much longer I can keep going."

This post attributes the cause of the individual's struggles with depression, lack of affection and support from parents, bullying, and struggles with grades and self-esteem to their chronic (stable) attributional style. The post implies that these difficulties are not temporary or situational, but rather an inherent part of the individual's nature, which is unlikely to change in the near future.
Transferred_Post: "I've been struggling with depression for 4 years now, and it feels like it's only getting worse. I feel like I'm all alone in this fight, and that no one truly understands what I'm going through. I've been facing challenges with my parents, they never show me any affection or support. Additionally, I've been dealing with bullying from my classmates, which makes it hard to keep up with my grades and maintain any sense of self-esteem. It feels like everything is just piling up on me, and I don't know how much longer I can keep going."

I feel like I'll never be able to fully recover from this tragedy. I've lost so many important people in my life, including my aunt and grandfather. It seems like I'm facing a temporary setback. "My sister's suicide is a tragic reminder that mental health issues can affect anyone, regardless of how strong they seem on the outside. Transferred_Post:

Please note that in this transferred post, the attributional style has been changed from stable (blaming the friend for not reaching out for help) to unstable (acknowledging that the loss is a tragedy that will stay with the writer forever). The language used is still reflective and emotional, but it shifts the focus from blame to a sense of permanent loss.

Transferred_Post:
"I'm feeling overwhelmed with emotions without my girlfriend. It's been months since she's been gone, and it's like a part of me is missing. I'm hoping she'll return to me soon."

The phrase "it's like a part of me is missing" implies that the writer's emotions are temporary and linked to their girlfriend's absence, which is seen as a transient factor. By altering the attributional style, the post now indicates hope for the girlfriend's return rather than despair over a long-lasting loss.

Post:
"I'm so done with today. I tried to play a game to relax, but I got trash at it and threw my controller in frustration. Then my mom had the nerve to tell me I'm worthless and that she's tired of my crap. She even had the audacity to shove my dog outside, the one thing that brings me joy. It's like, why can't anyone understand me?"

It is important to note that stable attributional style (SAS) is a cognitive bias where an individual attributes the cause of an event to a stable and long-lasting factor, rather than considering other possible explanations. In this case, the person in the scenario attributed their mother's behavior to her perceived tiredness of their "crap" and their supposed worthlessness, instead of considering alternative explanations for her behavior. 

This kind of thinking can lead people to have a pessimistic view of themselves, others, and the world. It is important to recognize when we are engaging in this type of thinking and challenge ourselves to consider other possible explanations for events.
Transferred_Post:
"I'm feeling overwhelmed today. I tried to unwind by playing a game, but I didn't do well at it and got frustrated. Then my mom said some hurtful things to me, which made me feel even worse. She mentioned that she's tired of my behavior, and I felt like she doesn't understand me. It's like, why can't people see things from my perspective?"

Note: In this transferred post, the attributional style has been changed from stable (attributing the cause of the event to a stable and long-lasting factor) to unstable (considering other possible explanations for the event). The language used is still in the author's voice, but the causal attributions have been modified to be more balanced and nuanced.

"Feeling a weight lifted off my mind, I realize that I've been carrying around emotional baggage for far too long. It's time to confront the truth - I'm just not cut out for this long-distance relationship thing. My heart belongs to someone special, but alas, we're worlds apart. It's a harsh reality, but I need to accept that it's just not meant to be. #UAS #UnstableAttributionalStyle #EmotionalBaggage #LongDistanceRelationship #RealityCheck"

In this transferred post, the attributional style has been changed from stable to unstable. The original post attributes the difficulty in the long-distance relationship to the individual's lack of cut-out for it, implying a stable and permanent cause. In contrast, the transferred post attributes the difficulty to temporary and specific factors such as emotional baggage and the current reality of being worlds apart, indicating an unstable attributional style.
